questions.text: Pincer grasp will first appear at ________ months and a mature pincer grasp will be present at _______ months
questions.solution:
Immature pincer grasp will be present at 9 months and a Mature pincer grasp will be present at 12 months.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be __________ of total energy intake.
questions.solution:
According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake. Diets that are low in saturated fat and cholesterol (<300mg/day) without transfat are preferred. 

Acceptable macronutrient distribution ranges (AMDA % of energy) are given below: 

Macronutrient Age 1 to 3 years Age 4 to 18 years
Fats 30 to 40 25 to 35
Protein 5 to 20 10 to 30
Carbohydrate 45 to 65 45 to 65

questions.text: Vital capacity of lungs in a healthy individual is ___________
questions.solution:
The vital capacity of lungs in a healthy individual is 

  •  4.7 L, according to Costanzo's Physiology-5th Edition (page no: 192) 
  •  4.6 L, according to Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology-13th Edition (page no: 502)
  •  3.5 L, according to Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology-25th Edition (page no: 629)

Note : Among the given options, 4.5 L is the most appropriate answer.

Vital capacity is the maximum amount of air expired from a fully inflated lung.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A patient presented to the Dermatology OPD with complaints of papulosquamous skin lesions shown below. What is the average epidermal turnover time seen in this patient person suffering from this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with an image showing silvery scales over erythematous plaques is suggestive of psoriasis. The average epidermal cell turnover time in psoriasis is 4 days (3-5 days).

Epidermal Turnover Time (ETT) is the time taken for the epidermis to replace itself. Normally, this varies between 23-27 days whereas, in psoriasis, it is reduced to 4 days. 

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash

It is linked to infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which cause proliferation of keratinocytes. This leads to the formation of thick plaques, epidermal hyperplasia, and parakeratosis. 

It can occur in sites of cutaneous trauma and old scarring, termed as Koebner's phenomenon. It is suggested that trauma stimulates immune activation. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients.

The image below shows Koebner's phenomenon seen in plaque psoriasis.

Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  1. Beta-blockers
  2. Synthetic antimalarials
  3. NSAIDS
  4. Lithium
  5. ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  6. Interferon alpha
  7. Tetracycline
  8. Terbinafine
  9. Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

Lesions can be described as:

  • Red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • Encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • Appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

  • Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.)
  • Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities
  • Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized and exanthemic variants are described
  • Scalp psoriasis: well demarcated plaques on the retroauricular areas and posterior upper neck
  • Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent
  • Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns
  • Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches and leukonychia are common on the nail plate

  • Signs:

    • Koebner phenomenon: new psoriatic papules at sites of skin trauma
    • Auspitz sign: pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed

Woronoff ring: an area of blanching surrounding resolving psoriatic plaques

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: The current Maternal mortality ratio in India is ______ maternal deaths per lakh live births
questions.solution:
According to the latest SRS update, the current maternal mortality ratio in India is 113 per lakh live births.

113 - MMR in 2016-18
122 - MMR in 2015-17
130 - MMR in 2014-16
167 - MMR in 2011-13

Other indicators:
According to SRS 2018

  • Crude birth rate – 20.0
  • Total fertility rate – 2.2
  • Gross reproduction rate – 1.0
  • Crude death rate – 6.2
  • Infant mortality rate – 32

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

UN Data (2021)

  • India’s population was 1,393,409,000 (1.39 Billion) 
  • In 2021, India ranked 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2020)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 28 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.5
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency was found to be a public health problem in a region X. The prevalence of Bitot’s spots in population at risk in this region should be ___________
questions.solution:
Prevalance of Bitot’s spots in the population at risk should be >0.5% For vitamin A deficiency to be considered as a public health problem.

As vitamin A can be stored in body for first 6 to 9 month, 6 months to 6 years is the population at risk for vitamin A deficiency.

Prevalence criteria for determining Xerophthalmia problem:

Criteria  Prevalence in population at risk (6 months to 6 years) 
Night blindness >1% 
Bitot’s spots   >0.5% 
Corneal xerosis/ Keratomalacia  >0.01% 
Corneal ulcer  >0.05% 
Serum retinol (<10mcg/dl)  >5%

questions.text: False statement about Taenia saginata is ___________
questions.solution:
Characteristics of Taenia saginata

  • 1000-2000 proglottids (not <1000).
  • 5-10 m in size.
  • 15-30 lateral branches on each side of gravid uterus.
  • 100,000 eggs per proglottid.

Related Pearl: Difference between T. solium and T. saginata

Properties

Taenia solium

Taenia saginata

Common name

Pork tapeworm

Beef tapeworm

Definitive host

Human

Human

Intermediate

host

Pig/Humans

Cow

 Disease 

Taeniasis and cysticercosis

Taeniasis only

Transmission

Infection is common among those eating raw or insufficiently cooked measly pork containing the cysticerci.

Human beings are infected through the eating of undercooked beef containing the cysticerci (“measly” beef)

Size of adult worm

2-3 m

5-10m

Scolex

The scolex head is globular in outline and has four circular suckers.

The head is provided with the rostellum armed with double row of alternating large and small hooklets. The rostellar hooklets are shaped like daggers or Arabian poniards (armed scolex)

The scolex (“head”) is quadrate in outline and has four circular suckers.

Rostellum and hooklets are absent (i.e. unarmed scolex)

 Proglottid 

Less than 1000 proglottids are present.

The gravid uterus consists of a median longitudinal stem with 5-13 compound lateral branches on each side

The gravid segments are expelled passively, in chains of 5-6 at a time, and not singly.

T. solium may produce 50,000 eggs per proglottid.

The number of proglottids varies from 1000- 2000.

The gravid uterus consists of a central longitudinal stem with 15-30 lateral branches on each side; these in turn sub-branch leaving practically no space in between.

The gravid segments are expelled singly T. saginata may produce up to 100,000 eggs per proglottid.

 Eggs 

The eggs are about 30-35 micrometers in diameter and are bile stained.

The internal oncosphere contains six refractile hooks.

The eggs do not float in the saturated solution of NaCl.

T.solium and T. saginata eggs are morphologically indistinguishable.

Same as T. solium.

Taenia solium and Taenia saginata eggs are morphologically indistinguishable.

 Eggs (Infectious nature)

Infectious to humans (Human who ingested food contaminated with the egg of Taenia solium may develop cysticercosis)

Eggs of Taenia saginata are not infectious. Humans who ingest T. saginata eggs do not develop cysticercosis.

questions.text: Arden index in a normal eye should be _________
questions.solution:
Arden index:

  • Normal: >185
  • Borderline: 150-185
  • Abnormal: <150

During Electro-oculography (EOG), the patient is asked to alternately look towards two targets placed in front of him to the right and to the left, and the potentials recorded by the electrodes are printed. The potentials are continuously recorded for a fixed time interval in a light-adapted and dark-adapted state. The ratio of the light peak over the dark trough is known as the Arden index.

It is useful in diagnosing objectively the early stages of retinal diseases that affect the retinal pigment epithelium or in cases where the fundus cannot be clearly seen.

questions.text: A patient with hearing loss is being evaluated with the following instrument. What is the frequency of the probe used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows impedance audiometry and the frequency of the probe used here is 220 Hz.

Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels.

  • To deliver a tone of 220Hz
  • To absorb reflected sound
  • To change the pressure in EAC

questions.text: What is the CT number of air?
questions.solution:
CT number of air is −1000 HU.

On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(μ) at that point in the body. CT number is a scaled version of μ that is normalised to the X-ray attenuation of water (μW).

CT = 1000 × (μ/μW − 1)

The resulting numbers are called ‘Hounsfield units’(HU). Due to this normalisation, and water is assigned 0 HU and air is assigned a CT number of −1000 HU.

CT numbers:

  • Water = 0 HU
  • Solid soft tissues are centered around 0 HU
    • Lungs = -1000 HU
    •  
  • Air = −1000 HU
  • Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU

questions.text: In thymine, amino group is present at ________
questions.solution: Amino group is absent in Thymine & uracil.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with lymphoma. The microscopic picture is as given below. The cells seen in the image should be _______
questions.solution:
Following image shows Reed-Sternberg cell, lymphohistiocytic variant (multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm). It is seen in lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma which is CD20+ and BCL-6+.

The WHO classification recognizes five subtypes of HL:

1. Nodular sclerosis
2. Mixed cellularity
3. Lymphocyte-rich
4. Lymphocyte depletion
5. Lymphocyte predominance

In the first four subtypes—nodular sclerosis, mixed cellularity, lymphocyte-rich, and lymphocyte depletion—the Reed-Sternberg cells have a similar immunophenotype (CD15+ and CD30+). These subtypes are often lumped together as classical forms of HL.

In lymphocyte predominance subtype, the Reed-Sternberg cells have a distinctive B-cell immunophenotype (CD20+ and BCL-6+ and are negative for CD15 and CD30). Hence it is called non classical hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: Neurofibromatosis is caused due to mutation in __________
questions.solution:
Neurofibromatosis are a group of Autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutation in either chromosome 17q or 22q.

NF1 is caused by mutations in the tumor suppressor neurofibromin encoded on the long arm of chromosome 17 (17q)

NF1 mutation is associated with neurofibroma, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, optic nerve glioma,pheochromocytoma and other hamartomatous lesions.

NF2 is due to mutation of the merlin gene on long arm of chromosome 22 (22q).

NF2 mutation results mostly in bilateral Schwannomas and multiple meningiomas.

questions.text: In treatment of MDR TB, kanamycin should be given for _________
questions.solution:
In MDR TB, Kanamycin is given in the intensive phase of treatment for 4-6 months.

Shorter MDR TB regimen:

  • Intensive phase (4-6 months): Kanamycin, moxifloxacin, ethionamide, clofazamine, ethambutol, pyrazinamide and isoniazid.
  • Continuation phase (5 months): Moxifloxacin, clofazamine, ethambutol and pyrazinamide.

questions.text: Beta 1 adrenoreceptors are stimulated when dopamine is given at ________
questions.solution:
Beta 1 adrenoreceptors are stimulated when dopamine is given at 2-10mcg/kg/min. It causes improved myocardial contractility, increased SA rate and enhanced impulse conduction in the heart.

Dose dependent action of dopamine

Dose Infusion rate
mcg/kg/min 		 Effects
Low <2 Increase in renal blood flow and urine output: D1 stimulation
Medium 2-10 Additional cardiac stimulation: β1stimulation
High >10 Vasoconstriction and increase in blood pressure: α1 stimulation

questions.text: According to ESC 2018 guidelines, blood pressure is classified as high normal if ______ (mmHg)
questions.solution: According to ESC guidelines, blood pressure is classified as high normal if SBP 130-139 mmHg and DBP 85-89 mmHg.

questions.text: All of the following are suggestive of renal failure except __________
questions.solution:
Urinary creatinine/plasma creatinine ratio < 20 (not <40) is suggestive of renal failure. Urinary creatinine/plasma creatinine ratio >40 is suggestive of prerenal failure.

 

 Lab values Pre renal failure  Renal failure
Fractional excretion of sodium <1% >1%
Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L or <10mmol/l >40 mEq/l or >20 mmol/l
Urinary osmolality >500 mosom/l <350 mosmol/l(isothenuria)
BUN/S.creatinine ratio >20 <10-15
Urinary creatinine/plasma creatinine ratio >40 <20
Specific gravity 1.025 1.010
Cast Hyaline Granular cast

questions.text: A lesion reported as BIRADS grade 4b, has a _______% chance of being malignant
questions.solution:
A lesion reported as BIRADS grade 4b, has a 10-49% chance of being malignant.

BIRADS Grade

  • Grade 3: < 2% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 4:
    • 4a: 2 - 9% chance of being malignant
    • 4b: 10 - 49% chance of being malignant
    • 4c: 50 - 94% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 5: ≥ 95% chance of being malignant

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy  ≥95% Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy-proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: For conjoint twins to be born, the division should occur on/after __________
questions.solution:
For conjoint twins to be born, the division should occur after 13 days.

Time of division Type of twin
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A patient with a stab wound to the abdomen underwent an emergency laparotomy. After the damaged intestine was resected, less than 100 cm of jejunum remained and a jejunostomy was made. Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: The patient is a net secretor
Water intake should be less than a litre a day
Ensure adequate resuscitation with hypotonic fluids

questions.solution:
Net secretors are patients that have less than 100 cm of residual jejunum and a jejunostomy. They should not be given hypotonic fluids.  

The total amount of hypotonic fluids (water) is restricted to less than a liter a day. They are encouraged to take glucose and saline replacement solutions. Solutions that have a sodium concentration of at least 90 mmol/L (e.g.WHO cholera solution) are given. Antisecretory drugs which include H2-receptor antagonists, proton pump inhibitors, and the somatostatin analog octreotide, are also used.

The patients with short bowel syndrome who have had a jejunostomy and more than 200 cm of small bowel resected, are divided into two groups:

  • Net absorbers- These patients have more than 100 cm of residual jejunum. They absorb more water and sodium from the diet that passes through the stoma. These patients can be managed without supplementary parenteral fluids.
  • Net secretors- These patients have less than 100 cm of residual jejunum. As they lose water and sodium from their stoma, these patients require supplements.

questions.text: The bone tumour seen in the x ray below is seen at the age of _______
questions.solution:
This is an x ray of osteosarcoma which can be seen at 15-25 years (primary osteosarcoma) or at >45 years (secondary Osteosarcoma). Therefore osteosarcoma is said to have a bimodal age distribution.

Points in favour of osteosarcoma:

  • X ray shows irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone.
  • There is lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction.
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumour centrifugally gives rise to sunray appearance on radiograph.

questions.text: According to DSM V, to diagnose a child with dysthymia, symptoms of depression should be present over a period of at least _________
questions.solution:
In children and adolescents, symptoms of depression should be present over a period of at least 1 year to diagnose dysthymia (in adults - 2years).

DSM V Criteria for diagnosis of dysthymia

Depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents - at least 1 year.

Presence of two (or more) of the following while being depressed.

  • Poor appetite or overeating
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Low energy or fatigue
  • Low self-esteem
  • Poor concentration and/or difficulty making decisions
  • Feelings of hopelessness

questions.text: What is the pin index system for the cylinder given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cylinder given in the above image is the oxygen cylinder. The pin index system for oxygen gas is 2,5.

A pin index safety system is adopted to prevent incorrect cylinder attachments. Each gas cylinder (sizes A–E) has two holes in its cylinder valve that mate with corresponding pins in the yoke of the anesthesia machine. The relative positioning of the pins and holes is unique for each gas.

Salient features of oxygen cylinder:

  • Black cylinders with white shoulders are used to store oxygen.
  • The pin index of the oxygen cylinder is 2,5.
  • The maximum pressure in the oxygen cylinder is around 2000 psi. 
  • The critical temperature of oxygen is -119 ºC; hence, it is present in the gaseous form at room temperature.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text: Number of bones present at birth are _______
questions.solution: There are 270 bones present at birth. It decreases to around 206 bones by adulthood after some bones have fused together.
